title: UK coastal walks: Torridon, Scotland
text: Torridon's rugged mountains, loch waters and green deer parks hold some of Scotland's best views. Even without the summits of mountains such as Beinn Eighe, lower-level exploration has much to offer, with the estate hosting a varied flora and fauna. • 10 reasons to visit Scotland this summer Seamus MacNally, property manager at Torridon said: “The hawthorn flowers on the bushes all along the shore path give the route a pleasant aroma, and there is plenty of wildlife to enjoy too. Ringed plover are out on the shingly shore, and come in close to the path when the tide is high." In season (early summer), you may spot stags growing new antlers under their soft velvety coats. Several walks have been mapped out across Torridon by the National Trust for Scotland; here we map out what they describe as the "red route" around the estate. Grade: Easy / moderate Terrain: There are unsurfaced and surfaced sections. Distance: 2 miles/3km Time: 45-60 mins OS Map: Landranger Sheet 24 The route Take the low-level path past the Deer Park: see these normally guarded animals up close, then find out how we manage them at the Deer Museum. • Scotland's best driving routes From the wildlife hide you might spot oystercatchers, sandpipers, mallard ducks and ringed plovers. Carry on along the shore path, and enjoy views down Loch Torridon – the Loch of Thorfinn’s town – to the atmospheric open-air meeting place. This is likely to have been a preaching site, used after the Disruptionof 1843. Some believe it was created long before the 19th century. • Great days out in the UK Red deer roam the area around Torridon Photo: AP For more on the route, see: nts.org.uk/Downloads/Walking/Torridon Facilities Parking Shop More great coastal walking holidays in Britain • Blakeney, Norfolk • Gower peninsula, Wales • Whitehaven, Cumbria • Prawle Point, Devon • White Cliffs of Dover • Old Harry Rocks, Dorset • Lindisfarne and Holy Island, Northumberland • Stonebarrow, Dorset • Runkerry, Northern Ireland • Stackpole, Wales Telegraphtravel Follow @telegraphtravel
